value.title: How to Create a Date or Calendar Table and Dimension in Power BI using Power Query
value.excerpt: Date dimension or calendar table is one of the most important dimensions in any BI system. In this video, I'm showing you how easy is to create a date dimension using Power Query. The script of this video can be found in my blog article here:  https://radacad.com/create-a-date-dimension-in-power-bi-in-4-steps-step-1-calendar-columns

value.title: Replace BLANK with Zero in Power BI Visuals Such as Card
value.excerpt: If you use a field in a visual and based on a combination of slicer selection, that field doesn't have any value, you might see blank in the visual. If you want to replace that blank to zero, here is a trick for you. a very simple trick that you can use anywhere easily. Read more details in my blog post,

value.title: Analyzing a slow report query in DAX Studio
value.excerpt: Investigate a slow query in a Power BI report using DAX Studio, looking at the query plan and the server timings. How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/ Optimizing DAX Workshop: https://www.sqlbi.com/p/optimizing-dax-video-course/

value.title: Computing a measure in DAX Studio
value.excerpt: You can use DAX Studio to evaluate one or more measures in your data model. This is the first step to write, test, and debug your DAX measures in a productive manner.  How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/

value.title: Creating a calculated table with DAX Studio

value.title: Import vs DirectQuery in Power BI

value.title: Describe Power BI Desktop models
value.excerpt: In this module, you'll learn about the Power BI Desktop model structure, star schema design basics, analytics queries, and report visual configuration. This module provides a strong foundation on which you can learn to optimize model designs and add model calculations.

value.title: Churn Classification Model Comparison with Power BI and Python
value.excerpt: The dashboard was created with Powerbi and Python using three classification algorithms; Random Forest, XGBoost, and Logistic Regression.  The models were used to classify customer churn across a telecommunications company dataset of 7k customers. I wanted to visualize the performance with PowerBI instead

value.title: DAX Fridays! #11: Using variables in DAX
value.excerpt: Variables are an extremely useful feature in DAX, but perhaps not a well known one. Variables, 1. Make your formulas more readable 2. You can reuse them through your report 3. Can also be tables 4. Are more efficient  Download our Growth dashboard if you want to see the example live:http://curbal.com/blog/the-ultimate-dashboard-to-track-your-website-growth-with-google-analytics-and-power-bi-supercharged-excel
